65.23.text:
If you're unfamiliar with carbon fibre it's
useful to understand what this material is

69.00.text: before your start working with it.

70.96.text:
Carbon fibre parts are actually 'carbon fibre
reinforced plastic' which is to say that they

75.25.text:
are a composite material made from a plastic
(normally a cured resin) which is reinforced

80.68.text:
by carbon fibres. It's important to understand
this because both the resin and the carbon

87.75.text:
fibres present both their own risks and considerations
when cutting the cured composite.

94.36.text:
When cutting or shaping carbon fibre parts
it is important to follow good safety practices.

98.95.text:
If you do so then cutting this material can
be made perfectly safe.

102.45.text:
The weight of evidence to date from studies
specifically into the dangers of working with

106.16.text:
carbon fibre overwhelmingly suggest that it
presents similar risks, and should be protected

110.64.text:
against in a similar way, to working with
other dense materials like hardwood or fibreglass.

115.70.text:
In addition, some resin systems may produce
toxic smoke when cut using high speed machines.

121.41.text:
The main risks are irritation to skin, eyes
and lungs caused by fine dust particles and

127.23.text:
danger from splinters and sharp edges of the
cut laminate. If you're using high-speed cutting

131.23.text:
tools then there are the risks associated
with that sort of equipment.

135.25.text:
One final risk comes from the fact that carbon
fibre dust is electrically conductive, although

139.30.text:
in practice this is more of a risk to your
electrical tools and equipment rather than

145.29.text:
All risks and irritation from carbon fibre
dust can be significantly reduced by working

149.89.text:
in a well ventilated environment and ideally
with some localised extraction. In a workshop

154.88.text:
environment that might working with a positionable
extraction arm like this.

160.12.text:
Or even working on a down-draught table like.
Now these will draw dust down into the filter

166.12.text: before even gets a chance to be airborne.

168.30.text:
But, if you're working at home or doing more
infrequent jobs then something as simple as

173.53.text:
a vacuum cleaner, like this, positioned on
the table as near to where you're working

178.56.text:
as possible with do the same thing and suck
up dust as it's being created.

184.19.text:
Carbon fibre dust itself is NOT toxic however
fine particles of it can irritate your lungs

189.30.text:
in the same way that cutting materials like
hardwood can.

192.46.text:
The plastic element of carbon fibre parts
is most commonly a thermoset resin such as

196.60.text:
epoxy, polyester or vinylester. Of these,
epoxy resin specifically can produce toxic

201.94.text:
dust when cut using high-speed cutting equipment
and because it is often difficult to know

205.85.text:
which resin system has been used in the manufacture
of a part we would always suggest assuming

210.32.text:
that high speed cutting could create hazardous
or toxic dust and so take appropriate precautions.

216.70.text:
To safeguard against both risks, as well as
extraction or good ventilation, we always

221.24.text:
suggest wearing a respirator when cutting
carbon fibre.

of respirator that are available. We'd suggest

230.01.text:

they don't really have any guaranteed protection

237.24.text:

of fit either.

241.62.text:

this is a good starting point.

246.94.text:

this filters out finer dust particles and

252.80.text:
a valved example, like this one, is much more
comfortable to wear for long periods of time.

258.37.text:
For prolonged or regular use you might want
to look into a re-useable respirator like

262.37.text:
this one. These tend to offer a much better
fit ensuring that dust can't find its way

266.89.text:
around the mask. Again, look for P2 stamp
even a P3 rating which safeguards against

275.46.text:
The next safety consideration is your skin.
There's two risks to your skin when trimming

279.77.text:
carbon fibre parts; the first being cuts from
the sharp edges and the second from irritation

287.06.text:
If you're cutting down ready made carbon fibre
parts like, which could be a seat-post for

291.81.text:
example then you're very unlikely to encounter
any sharp or dangerous edges but if you're

297.27.text:
trimming freshly demoulded carbon fibre parts,
like this, then exercise great caution because

303.43.text:
the edges of the laminate where it goes thin
can be absolutely razor-sharp and give you

309.75.text:

is very common when cutting or sanding carbon

313.87.text:
fibre. This irritation is most likely to affect
your hands -- particularly in-between your

320.92.text:
Thin surgical gloves, like these, can be worn
to keep the dust off your skin but for heavier

325.44.text:
trimming operations we would always generally
opt for a disposable full suit as well.

331.11.text:
If you do get carbon fibre dust on your skin
then wash it off with cold water not warm

336.05.text:
or hot water. This will avoid opening your
pores and making the irritation worse.

340.04.text:
The last piece of safety equipment we would
recommend is eye protection.

344.13.text:
If you're only fettling or making small adjustments
to a carbon fibre part by hand then there

348.20.text:
is very little risk to your eyes but for any
heavier cutting or power tool use then safety

353.13.text:
glasses, like these, offer a good basic level
of protection or alternatively, for heavier

359.19.text:
trimming operations then a set of goggles
like these is recommended.

363.94.text:
There is nothing particularly difficult or
unique about cutting cured carbon fibre. Many

368.53.text:

expensive specialist tools but this is not

372.63.text:

make things quicker and easier but, if you

377.47.text:

you can certainly cut carbon fibre with fairly

383.60.text:
As a general rule, when cutting carbon fibre
you want the cutting surface for the tool

387.86.text:
you're using to be as fine as possible. A
finer cutting surface will splinter and fracture

392.36.text:
the laminate much less than a coarser cutting
surface. This means that the best blades to

396.80.text:
use don't in fact have teeth at all, instead
they either have a fine grit on their cutting

400.91.text:
edge like this Perma-Grit hacksaw blade, or,
like this slitting disc, which is made of

405.82.text:
a ceramic material which always gives it an
abrasive surface at the cutting edge.

411.22.text:
If you don't have a cutting tool with an abrasive
edge then you can still use toothed blades

414.93.text:
but you will find that they may chip and splinter
the laminate more when cutting.

419.27.text:
If you do use a blade with teeth then you
want the teeth to be as fine as possible.

423.69.text:

rather than those designed for wood in tools

cutting this can be rubbed away leaving a

after.
